ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to give and prepare a scientific presentation to your peers and get advice from people with different backgrounds.
Essential presentation practice in front of peers.
Learning to give scientific presentations, evaluate variety of research topics outside of my own discipline.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: 1. I really hope this course can be more like RIP talks in other department, to get more postdocs and PIs involved. Some other departments choose the hour before the happy hour every week, and not make it mandatory to graduate students, but still the room is always full of people. (I know it's hard to coordinate as several labs are on west campus, but Friday morning is only good for a class time but not for a RIP talk) 2. This course is well-organized, and the feedback form is helpful for evaluation. Josien and David invest a lot in this course and they always pay attention to your talk and take notes, this is really sweet.
This class MASSIVELY improved over last year. Managing the class was significantly more friendly, welcoming, and supportive than previous years.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Mandatory course does not need recommendation.
Yes, I recommend it to students who are not required to present yearly to their peers in this sort of forum.
Yes, it is interesting to explore different scientific topics and being able to convey your research to an intellectual and diverse audience.
